full_title_en: READMITS Score for Readmissions in Acute MI
medium_description_en: <span id="docs-internal-guid-592df9fd-7fff-9813-7998-f668eacfb225">Predicts 30-day readmission risk in patients admitted for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (not externally validated).
short_description_en: 30-day readmission risk after STEMI (not externally validated).
before_use: This calculator is not externally validated, and as such, should be used with caution.

seo.meta_description_en: The READMITS Score for Readmissions in Acute MI predicts 30-day readmission risk in patients admitted for myocardial infarction (not externally validated).
seo.keywords_en: Myocardial infarction, hospitalized, hospital readmissions, readmission risk, readmission score, AMI

how_to_use.use_case_en: Adult patients (≥18 years old) presenting with acute MI.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The Acute MI READMITS Score was developed to identify patients at increased risk of early hospital readmission.

  • Calculated using seven clinical and laboratory variables routinely available to clinicians during the first 24 hours of admission.

  • Based on EHR data and not yet externally validated.

  • There is a modest overestimation of readmission risk in the highest and lowest quintiles.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• May be useful from an administrative standpoint.

  • Early identification of patients at increased risk of 30-day readmission allows clinicians to implement targeted readmission reduction interventions (e.g. transition of care programs) for those patients.

  • Compared to alternative acute MI risk prediction models, such as the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) acute MI model, the Acute MI READMITS Score has demonstrated improved accuracy in identifying high-risk patients, and is more readily calculated in the clinical setting.

next_steps.advice_en:
• Should be calculated on the first day of hospital admission (model was designed so that all the required parameters would be available during the first 24 hours of hospital admission).

  • Patients identified as high-risk are most likely to benefit from targeted readmission reduction interventions (e.g. transition of care programs, which may include components such as reading materials, outpatient follow-up appointment scheduled prior to discharge, and others).

  • Readmission reduction interventions are most effective when implemented early in a patient’s hospital course.
next_steps.management_en: Readmission risk was strongly associated with clinical measures of severity. Therefore, early implementation of guideline-recommended acute MI treatments (i.e., early coronary intervention) likely plays an important role in preventing 30-day readmissions.

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
Nguyen et al (2018) derived and internally validated the Acute MI READMITS score through a retrospective evaluation of EHR data from 826 consecutive patients admitted with acute MI across 6 hospitals in northern Texas between 2009 and 2010. The primary outcome evaluated was all-cause, 30-day hospital readmission.

Two separate acute MI models were derived and internally validated from a list of candidate variables that were chosen based on previously published multi-condition readmission models, as well as clinical variables (e.g. comorbidities, markers of severity, laboratory results, etc) hypothesized to be likely predictors of adverse outcomes.

Although the “full-stay” model had slightly better discrimination, it did not significantly improve reclassification and was unable to be calculated until the time of discharge; the authors determined that the “first-day” or Acute MI READMITS Score was a more useful tool for clinicians. The Acute MI READMITS Score includes seven variables available within 24 hours of admission, allowing early risk assessment and institution of readmission reduction strategies.

The Acute MI READMITS Score demonstrated good overall discrimination (C-statistic 0.75, 95% CI, 0.70–0.80; optimism-corrected C-statistic 0.73, 95% CI, 0.71–0.7) and outperformed previously published multi-condition models and the CMS acute MI administrative model. However, the Acute MI READMITS model does demonstrate a modest overestimation of risk in the highest and lowest quintiles.

The Acute MI READMITS score has yet to be externally validated.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Nguyen OK, Makam AN, Clark C, Zhang S, Das SR, Halm EA. Predicting 30-Day Hospital Readmissions in Acute Myocardial Infarction: The AMI "READMITS" (Renal Function, Elevated Brain Natriuretic Peptide, Age, Diabetes Mellitus Nonmale Sex Intervention with Timely Percutaneous Coronary Intervention, and Low Systolic Blood Pressure) Score. J Am Heart Assoc. 2018;7(8).

creator_info.about_en: Oanh K. Nguyen, MD, MAS, is an assistant professor in residence at the University of California, San Francisco. She is also an associate editor for the Journal of Hospital Medicine. Dr. Nguyen’s primary research is focused on improving delivery of health care.
